Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Comprehensive Research on Cold-Formed Steel Sheathed Shear Walls: Special Detailing, Design, and Innovation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to close the knowledge gaps about the behavior of cold-formed steel lateral force resisting systems that use shear walls sheathed with steel or wood panels. The study includes three major tasks: 1) Configuring a unique testing method designed to investigate the performance of cold-formed steel shear walls under realistic loading conditions to provide reliable experimental data to evaluate the current code prescribed shear wall strengths. 2) Based on the experimental data, establish accurate analytical models to predict the shear strength of cold-formed steel shear walls made with different sheathing materials and to provide design equations based on the principles of mechanics and mathematical models. 3) Develop advanced designs of high-performance shear wall systems with enhanced ductility and strength for low cost building constructions in seismic and strong wind zones.

The results of this research will provide simplified and improved methodologies for safe and more economical design of building structures using the cold-formed steel shear walls which are known to be recyclable and provide better fire resistance compared to wood construction. This research will also make it feasible to use the cold-formed steel walls in taller buildings than what has been possible now in seismic and high wind regions. The educational activities of the project with the developments of hands-on experiments and teaching aids and a comprehensive text book will lead to improvements in teaching about the cold-formed steel structures to both graduate and undergraduate students. This will also promote professional interest in the use of this economical and sustainable method of building construction. Graduate students will receive advanced training in research methods through their direct involvement in the project research. The research results will be disseminated through publications in professional journals and conference proceeding as well as through a project website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project advances the cold-formed steel (CFS) building construction in three major perspectives: understanding the real behavior of CFS buildings in earthquake, producing the first analytical design method for CFS sheet shear walls, developing a high-performance CFS structural system for higher and more resilient CFS buildings.

The project developed a bi-directional testing method for CFS wall assemblies where lateral and vertical loads are applied to the wall concurrently to simulate the actual loading conditions in buildings. The project performed cyclic tests under the bi-axial loading conditions to study the failure mechanism and strength of CFS wall assemblies including both the shear walls and the bearing walls. The research discovered that the CFS shear walls demonstrated improved shear stiffness when a service level gravity load is applied while the shear strength was not significantly increased. CFS bearing walls, although not designed for shear resistance, yield significant amount of shear capacity, which shall be included in building system modeling and analyses.  The new experimental results help to establish more appropriate finite element models for CFS walls and buildings to access their seismic performance and assure safe design standards.

The project proposed a novel analytical model – Effective Strip Model for determining the capacity and deflection of CFS shear wall assemblies using thin-walled steel sheets. The new model provide the engineers the first time an analytical tool to predict the nominal strength and service drift for CFS sheet shear walls. It will help accelerate the design process and improve the design relatability.

The project developed an innovative CFS shear wall system using corrugated steel sheathing with optimal slit openings. The research discovered that with optimal slit sizes and patterns the CFS shear walls using thin-walled corrugated steel sheets can archive significantly increased shear strength, shear stiffness, and energy dissipation capacity which will allow CFS structures to be used in taller buildings in large earthquake and/or strong wind regions.

The education activities in the project involved establishing and organizing a student competition in CFS design, involving both undergraduate and graduate students in structural engineering research, and developing supporting materials for teaching CFS at college level. Those activities promoted higher education in CFS design and encourage students to use creative thinking skills to solve engineering problems.

The research findings and educational materials have been disseminated to the academic and engineering communities through journal publications, conference proceedings and presentations, new design provisions adopted in the North American Standard for Steel Framing Standards as well as a new book entitled “Recent Trends in Cold-Formed Steel Construction” published by Elsevier in 2016.
